title: Kevin Bryce
text:
Kevin Bryce (born 7 September 1988) is a <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who plays as a <a href="Hooker%20%28rugby%20union%29">Hooker</a> for <a href="Pro14">Pro14</a> side <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a>. He has also played at <a href="Prop%20%28rugby%20union%29">Tighthead Prop</a> and <a href="Flanker%20%28rugby%20union%29">Flanker</a> and has previously played for <a href="Edinburgh%20Rugby">Edinburgh</a> and <a href="Yorkshire%20Carnegie">Yorkshire Carnegie</a>.
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
Before professional club <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, Bryce played for <a href="Heriot%27s%20Rugby%20Club">Heriot's Rugby Club</a> in the <a href="Scottish%20Premiership%20%28rugby%29">Scottish Premiership</a>, still representing them between the odd cap for Glasgow.
Following the 2007 U19 international championship, Bryce was named the recipient for the John Macphail Scholarship for the 2007 season. The Scholarship will allow Bryce to develop his skills and play club rugby in <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, alongside experienced <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">All Black</a> players. Former plays to gain the scholarship include, <a href="John%20Barclay%20%28rugby%20union%29">John Barclay</a> and <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Sevens</a> player <a href="Graham%20Hogg%20%28rugby%20union%2C%20born%201987%29">Graham Hogg</a>.
It was announced that from the 2019-20 season, Bryce would be taking up a player-coach role at <a href="Glasgow%20High%20Kelvinside">Glasgow High Kelvinside</a>.
Professional career.
Bryce has only been playing professional rugby since February 2014, but has been involved in a professional set-up since the beginning of the 2013–14 season. He did initially join the Warriors on a short-term basis in February 2013 due to the loss of frontline hookers to international duty and injury, but was unable to earn a cap.
In May 2013, Bryce signed a one-year contract with <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a>, for the 2013–14 season. However, in December 2013, Bryce joined English club <a href="London%20Irish">London Irish</a> on loan to cover the international capped player, <a href="David%20Paice">David Paice</a>. However, Bryce did not play any games for London Irish.
He made his professional début for <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> on 23 February 2014 against the <a href="Dragons%20%28rugby%20union%29">Newport Gwent Dragons</a> during the 62nd minute.
In March 2014, after earning his first professional cap, Bryce signed a new contract with Glasgow Warriors, extending his stay at the <a href="Scotstoun%20Stadium">Scotstoun</a> until May 2016.
Bryce moved to Edinburgh in 2016. Edinburgh saw Bryce as a Tighthead Prop and he retrained in that role for the club.
He went on loan to <a href="Yorkshire%20Carnegie">Yorkshire Carnegie</a> in 2018.
On 9 July 2018 it was announced that <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> had re-signed Bryce. In their statement, the club's forward coach <a href="Jonathan%20Humphreys">Jonathan Humphreys</a> stated:
"I always preferred Kev as a hooker and he has a chance with us now to see if he can reach the high standards he achieved a few years ago when he was playing international rugby."
International career.
Kevin had played for Scotland at various age grade level. In 2006, he represented <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-18%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland under-18</a>'s, before representing <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-19%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland under-19</a>'s in 2007. During 2007, Bryce was part of the Scotland Under 19's team that went to the <a href="2007%20Under%2019%20Rugby%20World%20Championship">2007 Under-19 Rugby World Championship in Ireland</a>, in which Bryce played every match.
In a warm-up match against <a href="Italy%20national%20under-19%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy under-19</a> for the Under-19 Championship, Bryce captained the side from the Openside, in which Scotland under-19's lost 19–13.
In 2013, while playing for Heriot's, Bryce was selected for the winning Scotland Club XV side that beat an Ireland Club XV side 30–18 to reclaim the Dalriada Cup for the first time since 2009. He was one of 17 uncapped players in the squad, with Bryce making his appearance of the bench. Bryce was benched for the match against the France Club XV side, in which the Scottish side lost 44–10.
In January 2014, Bryce played for the <a href="Scotland%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland A</a> side against the <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> at <a href="Scotstoun%20Stadium">Scotstoun Stadium</a>. Bryce came off the bench in the 73rd minute, to play for his fourth Scottish national team - Scotland A drew 16–16 with the Saxons.
On 20 May 2014, Bryce was one of six uncapped players named in the 43-man dual-squad, for the <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scottish national side</a>'s summer tour to the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States</a>, <a href="Canada%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Canada</a>, <a href="Argentina%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Argentina</a> and <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a>. He was called up to Scotland's <a href="2015%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2015 Rugby World Cup</a> squad to replace the injured <a href="Stuart%20McInally">Stuart McInally</a>.
Coaching career.
It was announced that from the 2019-20 season, Bryce would be taking up a player-coach role at <a href="Glasgow%20High%20Kelvinside">Glasgow High Kelvinside</a>.
